name: Clean Energy
title: IFC selects Uruguay for its first global investment in green hydrogen
description:
The International Finance Corporation (IFC), a member of the World Bank Group, has announced its first global investment in green hydrogen, partnering with Spain’s Santander Group to develop Kahirós, the first project of its kind in Uruguay.
At a time when less than 5% of green hydrogen projects worldwide have reached the final investment stage, this milestone underscores IFC’s commitment to expanding access to diverse energy sources and highlights the potential for sustainable, scalable technologies in emerging markets.
The project will be financed through a US$20 million green loan from IFC and will integrate solar PV generation, green hydrogen production and electric freight transport.
As the first end-to-end green hydrogen solution for freight transport in Uruguay, it is expected to significantly reduce emissions in the logistics and forestry sectors and provide a model for the expansion of these clean technologies in other markets.
Our commitment is for Kahirós to become a regional and global benchmark from which to share lessons learned and new opportunities,” said María José González, Director of the Kahirós Project.
text:
The International Finance Corporation (IFC), a member of the World Bank Group, has announced its first global investment in green hydrogen, partnering with Spain’s Santander Group to develop Kahirós, the first project of its kind in Uruguay. The initiative aims to create jobs and position the country as a regional leader in scalable clean energy solutions.

At a time when less than 5% of green hydrogen projects worldwide have reached the final investment stage, this milestone underscores IFC’s commitment to expanding access to diverse energy sources and highlights the potential for sustainable, scalable technologies in emerging markets.

The project will be financed through a US$20 million green loan from IFC and will integrate solar PV generation, green hydrogen production and electric freight transport. Solar energy will power an electrolyser that produces green hydrogen to supply a fleet of six trucks specifically designed to transport timber to Montes del Plata, a major Uruguayan pulp mill and one of the country’s largest industrial exporters.

This system is expected to cut 870 tonnes of CO₂ emissions per year—equivalent to removing more than 300 cars from the road—and lay the foundation for a new industry with the potential to create over 30,000 direct jobs by 2040.

“Uruguay has made remarkable progress in scaling up renewable energy, and this project represents an important step in the decarbonisation of hard-to-abate sectors such as transport,” said Alfonso García Mora, IFC Vice President for Europe, Latin America and the Caribbean. “The World Bank Group is committed to supporting pioneering and innovative projects that create quality jobs and serve as replicable models across Latin America and beyond.”

Gustavo Trelles, Country Head of Santander Uruguay, added: “Santander is driving Kahirós because we are convinced of its transformative potential, and IFC’s participation confirms the strength and global relevance of this initiative. This partnership reflects exemplary synergy between institutions committed to leading the energy transition and demonstrating that Uruguay can set the pace towards a more sustainable future.”

Kahirós is a consortium formed by Uruguayan companies Ventus (renewable energy developer), Fidocar (automotive sector) and Fraylog (logistics operator), together with Santander Group and with financial backing from the UN’s Renewable Energy Innovation Fund (REIF). Operations are scheduled to begin in late 2026. As the first end-to-end green hydrogen solution for freight transport in Uruguay, it is expected to significantly reduce emissions in the logistics and forestry sectors and provide a model for the expansion of these clean technologies in other markets.

“We are proud to contribute to the innovation needed for a sustainable energy transition. As we said when the project was launched, this is another step to strengthen Uruguay’s position as a strategic hub for the development of this new technology and for attracting further investment. Our commitment is for Kahirós to become a regional and global benchmark from which to share lessons learned and new opportunities,” said María José González, Director of the Kahirós Project.

name: Detroit and Evs
title: Ford partners with Renault to build more EVs for Europe - USA Today
description:
Ford Motor and Renault Group are entering into a strategic partnership to expand Ford's electric vehicle offerings in Europe.
The automakers have also signed a letter of intent to explore jointly developing and manufacturing light commercial vehicles.
Under this letter, the companies "will explore the opportunity to jointly develop and manufacture" certain Ford and Renault light commercial vehicles, Ford said in a statement.
“We need to enable everyone to benefit from electrification and letting customers choose — whether that’s fully electric or hybrid vehicles,” Ford Europe President Jim Baumbick said in a statement.
Ford’s current range of electric vehicles from the alliance are produced at its new Electric Vehicle Centre in Cologne, Germany."
text:
Ford Motor and Renault Group are entering into a strategic partnership to expand Ford's electric vehicle offerings in Europe.

The collaboration will produce 2 new Ford-branded EVs built on Renault's Ampere platform, expected to launch in early 2028.

The automakers have also signed a letter of intent to explore jointly developing and manufacturing light commercial vehicles.

Ford Motor Co. entered into a "strategic partnership" with French-automaker Renault Group to expand Ford’s electric vehicle offering in Europe, a deal that will "significantly" improve the competitiveness for both companies in Europe, the companies said Dec. 9 in a statement.

The collaboration, which is not a joint-venture, will involve the automakers developing two distinct Ford-branded EVs, Ford's statement said.

Additionally, the two auto companies have signed a Letter of Intent for a European light commercial vehicle collaboration. Under this letter, the companies "will explore the opportunity to jointly develop and manufacture" certain Ford and Renault light commercial vehicles, Ford said in a statement.

The two new EVs will be based on the Ampere platform — that's Renault's EV arm dedicated to designing advanced and affordable EVs. For Ford, the partnership means leveraging Renault's EV assets and competitiveness. The vehicles will be made by Renault Group in the north of France using Ampere’s ElectriCity’s “state-of-the-art” manufacturing expertise.

For Renault, the two vehicles, which are expected to come to market in early 2028, will be designed by Ford. The EVs will feature "distinctive driving dynamics, authentic Ford-brand DNA and intuitive experiences" and mark the first step in a new product offensive for Ford in Europe.

“As an American company, we see Europe as the frontline in the global transformation of our industry,” Ford CEO Jim Farley said in a statement. “How we compete here, how we innovate, partner, and invest — will write the playbook for the next generation. We are committed to a vibrant future in Europe, but that future requires us to move with greater speed and efficiency than ever before.”

Ford and Renault take on the Chinese

Farley added that the partnership is an important step for Ford and supports "our strategy to build a highly efficient and fit-for-the future business in Europe. We will combine Renault Group’s industrial scale and EV assets with Ford’s iconic design and driving dynamics to create vehicles that are fun, capable and distinctly Ford in spirit."

Farley has been vocal about the importance of being competitive in EVs against Chinese manufacturers, which are known for making high-quality and affordable EVs, and have a growing footprint in Europe with major Chinese brands such as BYD and Geely gaining marketshare.

According to Schmidt Automotive Research, the marketshare for Chinese EVs in Western Europe is expected to increase to 11% this year or 269,450 vehicles, up from 9.6% in 2024. Western Europe includes Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Spain. That's a gigantic gain in marketshare given that in 2021 the Chinese EV companies had just 3.8% marketshare. But the research forecasts that Chinese EV marketshare will peak at 13% in 2028 then slide back to 11.7% in 2030 or 756,000 vehicles.

Currently, EVs represent a total of 16.1% of vehicles sold in Europe, Ford said, far below the required 25% of new vehicle registrations required to meet Europe’s strict CO2 targets by 2025.

“We need to enable everyone to benefit from electrification and letting customers choose — whether that’s fully electric or hybrid vehicles,” Ford Europe President Jim Baumbick said in a statement. “It is about making the transition more attractive and more affordable for all consumers and businesses, stimulating demand rather than stifling it.”

Ford and Renault leaders say that by joining forces in innovation, design, software and service delivery, will help them to address industry challenges and better serve retail and commercial customers.

“Our plan is about unleashing the Blue Oval,” Baumbick said. “We are leveraging strategic partnerships to ensure competitiveness, but we are obsessing over the product. These will be fun-to-drive, fully connected vehicles that stand out from the crowd.”

The gains from the partnership

When asked how much cost-savings and efficiency Ford hopes to gain from this partnership or how much revenue it forecasts coming from sales of these new EVs once they come to market, Ford Europe spokesman Dirk Ellenbeck told the Detroit Free Press, part of the USA TODAY Network: "The partnership combines the expertise, industrial scale and supply base of Ford and the Renault Group and will improve the competitiveness of both parties. We are not disclosing financials associated with this partnership."

But the partnership combines the expertise, industrial scale and supply base of two major companies to deliver efficiency and manufacturing scale.

François Provost, CEO Renault Group, said the collaboration reflects the strength of both companies' expertise and competitiveness in Europe.

"In the long term, combining our strengths with Ford will make us more innovative and more responsive in a fast-changing European automotive market," Provost said in a statement.

Ford's other partners

Ford has existing partnerships in Europe. Ford Otosan is its joint venture with Koç Holding, a Turkish investment company. That arrangement has helped support Ford's commercial vehicle business in Europe. Ford Otosan plants are supplied with electric drive units produced in the United Kingdom following a £380 million investment in the plant, and advanced engine technology from Ford’s Dagenham plant in England.

In 2020, Ford and Volkswagen AG agreed to develop commercial vehicles and a variety of passenger cars globally. Ford said the partnership is delivering "significant contributions to strengthening both our commercial vehicle and passenger car businesses. Ford’s current range of electric vehicles from the alliance are produced at its new Electric Vehicle Centre in Cologne, Germany."

At the same time, Ford is evolving its industrial operations in Europe to help it offer customers more choices for "multienergy vehicles." Ford’s plant in Valencia, Spain, will continue to play a critical role in realizing Ford’s plan for an enhanced passenger vehicle portfolio in Europe, the company said.

name: American Energy
title: The debate about nuclear energy must be reframed for the future
description:
Nearly 15 years after Fukushima, proponents and critics of nuclear energy remain deeply divided about the accident’s seriousness and nuclear energy more broadly.
Since its inception, discussion about nuclear energy has been marked by extreme polarization, with proponents and opponents seeming to inhabit separate worlds when making wildly different claims about the future of nuclear energy.
It became the first group to use non-violent methods to oppose nuclear weapons testing, frequently by attempting to enter or entering closed-off nuclear weapons testing sites.
The Sierra Club describes itself as being “unequivocally opposed to nuclear energy.” In its statement on nuclear energy, the Sierra Club points to nuclear safety, nuclear proliferation, and the long-term storage of nuclear waste as making “nuclear power a uniquely dangerous energy technology for humanity.”[11] Greenpeace’s statement on nuclear energy asserts that nuclear “has no place in a safe, clean, sustainable future.” The organization describes nuclear energy as both expensive and dangerous and asserts that “just because nuclear pollution is invisible doesn’t mean it’s clean.”[12] In another example, Friends of the Earth describes nuclear as a “slow and costly solution to the climate crisis” and “one that creates harmful waste we have no answer for.”[13] Nuclear professional and industry organizations—the American Nuclear Society, the Nuclear Energy Institute, the Electric Power Research Institute, and the Institute of Nuclear Power Operations, for example—have long favored the peaceful use of nuclear energy.
Ultimately, the polarizing debate around nuclear energy is obscuring a simple fact: Our shared energy future is uncertain.
text:
Nearly 15 years after Fukushima, proponents and critics of nuclear energy remain deeply divided about the accident’s seriousness and nuclear energy more broadly.

On March 11, 2011, an earthquake exceeding 9 on the Richter scale struck just off the East Coast of Japan. The earthquake caused a tsunami whose waves rose over 40 meters at their highest point and over 15 meters at the site of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, where they surged over the 10-meter-tall seawall, flooding the emergency diesel generators that were the main source of backup power for the plant, which had already lost connection to the electricity grid. Although the plant shut down, the fuel in the reactors continued to produce decay heat, gradually evaporating the water in which the fuel was initially submerged. This cooling water continued to boil and evaporate until the fuel itself became uncovered and began to melt.

Three of the reactors at the site experienced partial meltdowns (units 1, 2, and 3). Hydrogen generated by the overheated fuel ignited, causing explosions in three reactor buildings (units 1, 3, and 4) and widespread dispersion of radioactivity. It took three months of tireless effort before the plant staff could restore automatic cooling to the damaged units and another six months before the reactors were declared stable and in a state of “cold shutdown.” The makeshift arrangements needed to restore the reactors to a stable condition generated over 350 million gallons of contaminated water, now being filtered, diluted, and released into the Pacific Ocean. The radionuclides released during the reactor building explosions still contaminate the soil and air in the towns closest to the Fukushima Daiichi plant, and the decontamination work is ongoing.

Over 150,000 people were evacuated from the Fukushima prefecture in 2011. The latest estimates from November 2024 indicate that over 24,000 evacuees are still displaced, having resettled outside the area.

Many proponents of nuclear energy describe the events that unfolded at the Fukushima Daiichi plant as an extremely low-probability “accident” or, more specifically, a “beyond design basis accident” caused by a series of highly improbable events beyond human control. These proponents also describe the accident’s aftermath as a success story because it did not lead to any immediate radiation-related deaths. But for critics of nuclear energy, however, the very name of the Fukushima prefecture has become synonymous with disaster—a disaster they view as not at all unexpected, with many describing it as a “normal accident,”[1] meaning that it was inevitable (Perrow 2011).

Nuclear proponents use the Fukushima experience as evidence of why nuclear energy should not just continue to be used, but be used on a much larger scale, if the worst possible outcome is a Fukushima-like accident. Critics view the Fukushima disaster as a complete indictment of nuclear energy—calling not only for a halt to new reactor projects but also for shuttering existing reactors. Both sides, though seemingly drawing on the same set of facts, interpret them quite differently to reach their conclusions, with neither side offering a full picture.

Since its inception, discussion about nuclear energy has been marked by extreme polarization, with proponents and opponents seeming to inhabit separate worlds when making wildly different claims about the future of nuclear energy. In making these claims, proponents and opponents do not engage with one another, hoping to learn; rather, they try to evangelize, seeking to convince the other side of what they view as universal truths about nuclear energy.

These claims to absolute truth frequently rely on emotion, apocalyptic imagery, rigid logic, and separation of connected facts (what we call “rhetorical fission”) or connection of fragmented facts (what we call “rhetorical fusion”). Those claims are often divorced from the lived experiences—positive and negative—of people affected by nuclear power, whether through the benefits of greater access to reliable electricity and reductions in pollution and greenhouse gas emissions or, on the negative side, through accidents at power plants, the mining of uranium, and the storage of used nuclear fuel.

Here, we argue for a different way of discussing the many issues around the use of nuclear energy to provide electrical power, one that moves beyond rhetorical fission and fusion and acknowledges uncertainty and the place-based nature of the issue. This model asks proponents and opponents to think beyond their identities as advocates and bring previously unheard voices and forms of evidence to a deliberative co-creation of planetary futures.

How the nuclear debate arose

In the United States, the anti-nuclear movement began in the 1950s in response to the testing of nuclear weapons. The United States carried out 1,054 nuclear tests between 1945 and 1992, with 210 of these being atmospheric tests.[2] Anti-nuclear protests intensified with an increase in atmospheric weapons tests, particularly after those in the Bikini Atoll in the Marshall Islands led to fallout and widespread but unacknowledged health impacts for local communities.[3]

The Committee for Nonviolent Action (CNVA) was formed in 1957 in response to the US program of nuclear weapons testing. It became the first group to use non-violent methods to oppose nuclear weapons testing, frequently by attempting to enter or entering closed-off nuclear weapons testing sites. In 1957 members attempted to enter the Camp Mercury nuclear testing area near Las Vegas and made another attempt to enter the Eniwetok Proving Grounds in the Marshall Islands in 1958. Years later, CNVA’s attempts to enter these closed-off weapons testing sites would inspire Greenpeace protests.

Members of Greenpeace (who initially called themselves the “Don’t make a wave committee”) sailed to Alaska (on a ship called Greenpeace) in 1971 to stop a second nuclear weapons test on Amchitka Island.[4] Greenpeace’s activism against nuclear weapons testing spread to other countries as well. In France, Greenpeace activist David McTaggart played a central role in halting French nuclear weapons testing in the Pacific. Greenpeace’s activism, which began with a focus on nuclear weapons, shifted to also focus on the dumping of radioactive waste when, in 1993, a Greenpeace ship documented a Russian navy vessel dumping radioactive waste into the Sea of Japan, in violation of the London Convention, an international treaty created to control ocean dumping (McCullagh 1995).

In 1961, a group known as the Women’s Strike for Peace mobilized roughly 50,000 women to march in protest against nuclear weapons in over 60 US cities. This organization began tying nuclear weapons issues to the health and lived experiences of everyday people. They used slogans such as “End the Arms Race—Not the Human Race” and “Pure Milk, Not Poison.”[5] As an organization composed primarily of mothers, the Women’s Strike for Peace was particularly concerned about the health impacts of weapons testing on children. This strategy of connecting anti-nuclear weapons arguments with everyday health and safety issues is one that would hold sway across organizations for some time.

By the 1960s, the nuclear power industry had begun to take off. Light water reactors had emerged as the leading design for the United States, and reactor designers and electric utilities were scaling initial designs for plants capable of generating hundreds of megawatts of electricity. Over this same period, environmental groups such as Friends of the Earth and the Sierra Club began to raise concerns about nuclear energy.

Although initially pro-nuclear energy, the Sierra Club began to oppose to nuclear energy in the late 1950s, specifically in the form of the Bodega Head nuclear power plant planned by Pacific Gas and Electric for a coastal site in Northern California. This project was ultimately stopped as a result of the club’s opposition and grassroots efforts that cited concerns about the proposed plant’s proximity to the San Andreas fault. At that point, the Sierra Club did not express a blanket disapproval of nuclear power, and the group otherwise supported the use of nuclear energy. But a second nuclear plant project, Diablo Canyon on California’s central coast, which ultimately was built, divided the club, with many, including then-executive director David Brower, believing that the Sierra Club needed to take a more radical stance against nuclear energy (Wellock 1992). (The Club officially adopted an anti-nuclear energy stance in 1974 and extended that stance to include opposition to fusion energy in 1986, though it appears that its stance on fusion is now undergoing reversal).[6]

In 1969, Brower, facing opposition from the Club’s board, left to start a new organization, the Friends of the Earth, which, since its inception, framed opposition to nuclear energy as central to its mission—a stance that continues now. Since its founding, the organization has led campaigns to shut down existing reactors and prevent the construction of new ones. In so doing, it combined lobbying, public education, and direct action to great effect.

Public education efforts initiated by anti-nuclear organizations shared a common feature with similar efforts launched by nuclear proponents: Both assumed a naive public that lacked knowledge about nuclear power, and, with few exceptions, they made universal arguments, framing their stances on nuclear energy as the only possible answer for the technology’s future. See figure 1 below.

By the 1970s, US environmental groups began calling for a moratorium on nuclear power plant construction, with regional groups such as the SHAD (Sound-Hudson Against Atomic Development) Alliance, gathering widespread support in the aftermath of the 1979 Three Mile Island accident. SHAD succeeded in shuttering the Shoreham, New York, nuclear power plant before it even began operation.[7]

Though these efforts did not lead to a nationwide ban on nuclear energy, many states adopted moratoria on building nuclear plants, instituting conditions restricting new nuclear plant construction. California’s 1976 moratorium on nuclear energy, for example, curtailed new nuclear construction until a federal plan for nuclear waste disposal was created. Moratoria passed by Kentucky (1984), Wisconsin (1983), and Illinois (1987) all cited the absence of a federal nuclear waste management plan. Notably, all three states have fully or partially repealed their moratoria to allow new nuclear plant construction, with Illinois’s partial repeal specifically allowing for the construction of advanced and small modular reactors. As of this writing, nine states in the United States still have moratoria on new nuclear energy construction.[8]

Though having US origins, many environmental and anti-nuclear groups had significant influence in other countries. In 1976, Greenpeace, the Sierra Club, Friends of the Earth, and 20 other environmental groups came together to form the “Campaign for a Non-Nuclear Future,” which had a goal of opposing the development of nuclear power in New Zealand and promoting the use of renewable energy.

Another organization central to the nuclear debate is the Union of Concerned Scientists. Founded in 1969 by faculty and students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the organization combined scientific expertise, activism, and environmentalism. Its founders called for scientific research to be used for environmental preservation, and not the development of military technologies—including nuclear weapons.[9] The UCS would soon also play a role in a key debate about nuclear power.

In many countries, anti-nuclear power movements began as local protests against specific facilities and grew to become national in scope, gaining momentum in the aftermath of the Three Mile Island and Chernobyl accidents. In Germany, the anti-nuclear movement began in the 1970s with the opposition to a nuclear power project in the town of Wyhl (Glaser 2012). In France, large-scale protests began in 1971 against plans for the first light-water reactor at Bugey (Tompkins 2016).[10] In Australia, too, protests began in the 1970s against both uranium mining and the proposed Jervis Bay nuclear power plant (Candela 2017). In many European countries, these local movements gained the support of national environmental groups and helped shaped energy policy. These movements led to decisions to phase out nuclear power in Italy, Sweden, Belgium, and Spain. (The implementations of these phase-out plans have varied, and Belgium and Sweden recently reversed their national nuclear phase-out stances.) In the aftermath of the 2011 Fukushima accident, Germany embarked on a plan to shutter all of its nuclear power plants.

Over this period of growing opposition, the nuclear industry found some unlikely allies. Inspired by the Atoms for Peace program, astrophysicist Heinz Haber authored “Our Friend the Atom” in 1956. The book, on the benefits of nuclear power, was illustrated by works from more than 20 illustrators from Walt Disney Studios. (Haber was a science consultant to the studios’ founder, Walt Disney). It was also part of a nearly hour-long episode of the television series Disneyland. The book and the episode were an effort to rehabilitate the atom, following the destruction of Hiroshima and Nagasaki and the ongoing campaigns against nuclear weapons testing. In his writing, Haber acknowledged that the atom had become a “superb villain” but noted also that the power of the atom could be harnessed “for the welfare of all mankind” (Haber 1957). See Figure 2.

The book concluded with three chapters describing the three wishes the atom would grant humanity: power, food and health, and peace. Haber’s book and the Disneyland episode presented a utopian, inevitable vision for nuclear energy, without admitting to the realistic challenges of scaling up nuclear power as an energy source. See Figure 3 below.

In its efforts to promote nuclear power, the nuclear industry looked to researchers for guidance on how to engage with the public. In the late 1960s, emerging research on risk perception asserted that publics were seldom “rational” when weighing the risks of various technologies. Instead, studies found, public perception of risk is largely driven by emotion. The research showed that publics were willing to take on higher levels of risk for voluntary rather than involuntary activities, and that feelings of dread and lack of control heightened sensitivity to risks, leading individuals to focus on a bad outcome instead of the probability that it might occur—a probability that might be vanishingly small (Slovic 2016). One branch of research, led by noted physicist and nuclear expert Chauncey Starr, was rooted in what we know now as the “deficit model,” which suggested that the public’s perception of the riskiness of a technology was rooted in a deficit of knowledge.

Starr suggested that public perceptions of risk could be mediated and managed through better education and advertising (Starr 1969). The nuclear industry ran with these findings, launching campaigns to educate the public about nuclear power. This mode of engagement with the public became the norm and persisted for decades. Arguably, it persists today. In the 1980s, in the aftermath of the Three Mile Island accident, several energy utilities banded together to form the US Council for Energy Awareness. In its advertisements, the council, in an effort to win public approval, tied nuclear energy to another salient issue—dependence on foreign oil. See figure 4 below.

Although the proponents and opponents of nuclear energy created separate discourses, seldom admitting to each other’s existence, there is at least one instance of a collaboration between the two that unequivocally led to public good by improving both the design and governance of nuclear energy technologies. In 1972, the US Atomic Energy Commission convened hearings on the design of emergency core cooling systems—a vital safeguard in nuclear reactors. The hearings had been convened following controversy over the AEC’s safety standards. The AEC had been designed with dual conflicting missions—to both regulate and promote nuclear energy. The hearings revealed that these conflicting missions had left the AEC fundamentally compromised, with the developmental arm slowing down or defunding the work of the regulatory arm.

Leading up to and during the two-year period of the hearings, AEC insiders collaborated with the Union of Concerned Scientists (UCS) to uncover suppressed information. The UCS representatives at the hearings, Daniel Ford (an economist) and Myron Cherry (a lawyer) had no formal technical training but were coached by AEC dissenters and nuclear researchers from AEC laboratories. These dissenters supplied suppressed documents and helped the UCS’ representatives prepare their arguments concerning the flawed designs and simulations of emergency core cooling systems.

The hearings ultimately led to the collapse of the AEC and the creation of separate regulatory and developmental agencies. It also led to new safety standards for emergency core cooling systems, which were vital in light of the ongoing scale-up of nuclear energy (Wellock 2012). None of this would have been possible without collaboration across the “anti” and “pro” nuclear camps. Unfortunately, this collaboration marked but a brief détente. But perhaps this unlikely partnership between the AEC dissenters and the UCS activists presents a model of collaboration that we can repurpose for the present.

What the pro- and anti-nuclear debate looks like now

The rhetorical strategies applied by the anti- and pro-nuclear camps exhibit notable similarities. Nuclear opponents, starting with nuclear weapons activists, tended to vilify pro-nuclear individuals and organizations and frame anti-nuclear activists as “moral agents” and defenders of the environment and public health (Blain 1991). The nuclear proponents, on the other hand, have framed and continue to frame narratives of “nuclear necessity and inevitability” (Kinsella 2015). often linking nuclear energy to issues—such as fighting climate change, providing energy access and security, and more recently, powering AI—on which there is more widespread agreement. See Figure 4, above.

Across this history and the recent past, examples of polarized discourse tend to fall into five categories: emotion-driven arguments, apocalyptic imagery, rigid logic, separation of connected facts (rhetorical fission), or strategic combination of nuclear with more palatable issues (rhetorical fusion).

We use the term “rhetorical fission” to refer to arguments in which ideas that are not logically separable are disconnected to advance an argument. For example, claiming that the Fukushima accident is a story of success because there were no radiation-related deaths separates the many disastrous outcomes of the accident from a single fact about radiation. While technically correct, the argument paints an incomplete picture of the event and, to many people, rings untrue. Rhetorical fusion, on the other hand, combines nuclear arguments with other issues as a way to gain public acceptance. For example, advancing an anti-nuclear argument by associating energy with weapons. The argument is a misdirect in regard to the United States, where civilian nuclear power and the military nuclear arsenal have long been explicitly disassociated from one another.

Emotional and apocalyptic arguments tend to emerge from anti-nuclear organizations. The Sierra Club describes itself as being “unequivocally opposed to nuclear energy.” In its statement on nuclear energy, the Sierra Club points to nuclear safety, nuclear proliferation, and the long-term storage of nuclear waste as making “nuclear power a uniquely dangerous energy technology for humanity.”[11] Greenpeace’s statement on nuclear energy asserts that nuclear “has no place in a safe, clean, sustainable future.” The organization describes nuclear energy as both expensive and dangerous and asserts that “just because nuclear pollution is invisible doesn’t mean it’s clean.”[12] In another example, Friends of the Earth describes nuclear as a “slow and costly solution to the climate crisis” and “one that creates harmful waste we have no answer for.”[13]

Nuclear professional and industry organizations—the American Nuclear Society, the Nuclear Energy Institute, the Electric Power Research Institute, and the Institute of Nuclear Power Operations, for example—have long favored the peaceful use of nuclear energy. But recently a newer group of pro-nuclear individuals and organizations not populated by nuclear engineers and industry professionals has emerged. These groups view their support for nuclear energy as central to their identity. And here we see instances of rhetorical fusion, pulling identity politics into nuclear arguments. For example, Mothers for Nuclear, founded in 2016, says that after “many years of questioning and working at California’s last remaining nuclear plant,” the group’s members changed their mind about nuclear and now “support nuclear as our largest and most hopeful source of clean energy, vital to addressing some of our world’s biggest challenges: climate change, air pollution, and energy poverty.”[14] The Breakthrough Institute asserts that advanced nuclear technologies promise “clean, reliable power with strong safety profiles and increasing benefits for energy security, climate, and economic development,” while noting that these benefits “require[s] a regulatory system that is equipped to license modern technologies at scale, and overcoming commercial hurdles.”[15]

More recent pro-nuclear advocacy showcases an amalgam of appeals, combining pieces of nuclear stories with bits of pop culture and science to create persuasive nuclear narratives. Pro-nuclear individuals—self-styled and even described by others as “nuclear influencers”—have gone viral on Instagram and TikTok for their accessible commentary on nuclear energy. One such nuclear influencer, Isabelle Boemeke, describes her work as being “at the intersection of art, science, and activism” and “inspiring humans to solve the world’s problems with optimism.” She created her Isodope persona to “advocate for nuclear electricity as a solution to climate change and energy inequality.”[16] A number of other nuclear influencers who identify as millennials and Gen-Zers have also risen to prominence.

Both proponents and opponents have attempted to find a place in the zeitgeist through film. Two recent examples include the Atomic Bamboozle (a 2023 short anti-nuclear film that was showcased as part of the Sierra Club’s Nuclear-Free film series) and Nuclear Now (a 2022 pro-nuclear documentary film that was screened at several university campuses across the US). See figure at top of page.

Both sides imply that their arguments are meant to be universal. For the anti-nuclear organizations, there is no conceivable time or place in which nuclear energy is desirable. For pro-nuclear proponents and influencers, a world without nuclear energy is inconceivable.

What is notably missing from this debate are the voices of people without a public microphone—and those not ideologically aligned with either debate.

Changing the terms of debate for a better nuclear future

Nuclear debate needs to change, and we propose a strategy that can be applied by those on both sides of the issue. We advocate bringing new voices into the conversation and putting opposing points of view in conversation with one another. Specifically, we propose strategic and widespread community engagement as one way to shift the debate away from the absolutism, high drama, and other unsuccessful strategies described above. We acknowledge that community engagement is not new in nuclear contexts, but neither is it the norm, and to date it has almost always been initiated by experts seeking approval for a nuclear project.

For many years, the nuclear industry has operated on the decide-announce-defend model for siting new facilities. Of course, this approach has been met with much opposition, project delays—and in some well-known cases, like Yucca’s Mountain waste repository, complete rejection. This approach to finding a nuclear waste repository has been largely replaced with consent-based siting, although some argue that securing consent is not enough. Particularly in the fusion energy community, the focus has shifted to securing social license (Hoedl 2022), or ongoing public acceptance, for a project in a given context. Social license is largely established by creating trusted pathways for two-way communication between communities and experts, including opportunities to learn from one another. These are valuable strategies, but, importantly, this model still operates under a rubric of persuasion—experts trying to persuade non-experts to accept and maintain a nuclear energy project.

We are arguing for community engagement as a strategy for listening and learning without intent to persuade. These engagements would be purposely not centered on or initiated because of a proposed facility or siting. Instead, they would focus on co-learning activities, where experts from either side of the nuclear debate share information about nuclear energy, and community members share stories about their community. Nuclear proponents and opponents alike could create “listening committees” in their organizations to build trust, establish communication, and even empower communities to invite nuclear projects into their region, instead of the other way around. Alternatively, communities uninterested in nuclear infrastructure reach such a stance through internal deliberation and make it known to developers. This process can support local decision-making, instead of the current situation, in which context and nuance are sacrificed in efforts to win the debate and decisions become transformed into national movements—as has been the case for both anti- and pro-nuclear efforts.

In our research and teaching on community engagement, we have also found that collaborative “futuring” activities—that is, prompts that invite people to imagine desirable future scenarios—can be a powerful way to unpack differences in perspective and find common ground (Verma, Snyder & Daly 2024). When such a strategy is included in community engagements, we have seen people on both sides of the nuclear debate change their minds and open their minds to ideas they never expected to entertain. We know from history that finding common ground is possible even across the most contentious issues. The unlikely collaboration between the AEC dissenters and the UCS activists described above is one example; we are proposing a model to invite more collaborations in this vein and resolve our long-standing differences for a shared common good.

At the same time, community engagement can give voice to people who have lived with nuclear energy and its impacts, for better and for worse, and those insights may help shift us away from the current, polarizing debate. Residents of Fukushima, Japan, for example, have valuable insight into the real-life risk and opportunity of nuclear power. In our experience in Japan this summer, local residents shared nuanced and unexpected perspectives about living through and beyond the Fukushima Daiichi accident. In many cases, residents expressed gratitude for the power provided by the reactor and for the lessons learned by way of the accident. And while solar panels and wind turbines have replaced nuclear in this area, some hope nuclear energy will return. Other people were, of course, not supportive of nuclear, having witnessed mass displacement, loss of loved ones, and an ongoing decontamination effort with no end in sight. But even those who were not supportive were not waging unreasoned arguments against nuclear energy. At the end of our conversations, community members across perspectives shared an outdoor picnic, knowing that Fukushima’s energy future is uncertain, but also that community perspectives are part of the decision-making conversation.

We acknowledge that many organizations may disregard our proposal on the basis of time, cost, or efficiency. Ultimately, the polarizing debate around nuclear energy is obscuring a simple fact: Our shared energy future is uncertain. Arguing more loudly or aggressively is not going to change that situation. A willingness to bring in new perspectives, consider opposing ideas, and embrace uncertainty may be the fastest way toward the clean, safe energy future we all envision.

Endnotes

[1] The “normal accidents” framing was created by Charles Perrow in his eponymous 1984 book and has more recently been applied by him to describe the Fukushima Daiichi accident. Perrow, Charles. “Fukushima and the inevitability of accidents.” Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists 67.6 (2011): 44-52.

[2] See: Nuclear Matters Handbook https://www.acq.osd.mil/ncbdp/nm/NMHB2020rev/chapters/chapter14.html; United States Nuclear Tests July 1945 through September 1992 https://nnss.gov/wp-content/uploads/2023/08/DOE_NV-209_Rev16.pdf

[3] The US carried out 67 nuclear weapons tests in the Marshall islands between 1946 and 1958. The radioactive debris and waste from these tests was not contained until the 1970s when the Runit Dome was built.

[4] See: https://www.greenpeace.org/usa/our-history/

[5] See: https://jwa.org/thisweek/nov/01/1961/wsfp#:~:text=The%20Women%20Strike%20for%20Peace%20(WSP)%20was,levels%20in%20milk%20*%20Increased%20nuclear%20testing

[6] See: https://www.sierraclub.org/new-jersey/blog/2025/06/opinion-does-fusion-energy-deserve-another-look

[7] See: https://nvdatabase.swarthmore.edu/content/us-anti-nuclear-activists-and-community-members-force-closure-shoreham-nuclear-power-plant-1

[8] These include California, Hawaii, Maine, Massachusetts, Minnesota, New Jersey, Oregon, Rhode Island, and Vermont.

[9] Founding Document: 1968 MIT Faculty Statement: https://www.ucs.org/about/history/founding-document-1968-mit-faculty-statement

[10] Tompkins, Andrew S. Better active than radioactive!: anti-nuclear protest in 1970s France and West Germany. Oxford University Press, 2016.

[11] See: https://www.sierraclub.org/nuclear-free

[12] See: https://www.greenpeace.org/usa/climate/issues/nuclear/#:~:text=Nuclear%20energy%20has%20no%20place,doesn’t%20mean%20it’s%20clean.

[13] See: https://friendsoftheearth.uk/climate/should-we-use-nuclear-energy

[14] See: https://www.mothersfornuclear.org/all-about-us

[15] See: https://thebreakthrough.org/nuclear-energy-innovation

name: Louisiana American Energy
title: BP, Chevron Are Top Bidders at First Trump Gulf of Mexico Oil and Gas Auction
description:
Dec 10 (Reuters) - BP, Chevron and Shell were among the ‌top ​bidders on Wednesday at the ‌U.S.
government's first sale of oil and gas drilling rights in the ​Gulf of Mexico since 2023.
BP was the most frequent bidder, according to sale documents, followed by Chevron and Shell.
The auction's highest bid was nearly $18.6 million, from Chevron, for a block in the Keithley Canyon deepwater area.
MORE: Places the U.S. Government Warns Not to Travel Right Now Trump's law lowered the rate to encourage industry participation in lease sales.
text:
Dec 10 (Reuters) - BP, Chevron and Shell were among the ‌top ​bidders on Wednesday at the ‌U.S. government's first sale of oil and gas drilling rights in the ​Gulf of Mexico since 2023.

The auction, which ended with $279.4 million in high bids, was the first of 30 ‍mandated by U.S. President Donald Trump's ​tax cut and spending bill, which he signed into law in July.

His administration's plans for offshore ​leasing are a ⁠significant departure from that of his predecessor, President Joe Biden, which had planned for a historically small number of oil and gas auctions as part of an effort to move away from fossil fuels and address climate change.

"We're entering a new era of offshore American energy dominance," Matt Giacona, ‌acting director of the U.S. Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, said at the start of ​the ‌auction, which was broadcast online.

BOEM ‍said 30 companies ⁠submitted a total of 219 bids on 1.02 million acres, about 1.3% of the acreage offered.

BP was the most frequent bidder, according to sale documents, followed by Chevron and Shell. Other top bidders included Anadarko, LLOG Exploration Offshore, Talos Energy and Murphy Exploration & Production.

The auction's highest bid was nearly $18.6 million, from Chevron, for a block in the Keithley Canyon deepwater area. The second highest was a joint bid of $15.2 million from Woodside ​Energy Deepwater and Repsol for a block in the Walker Ridge area.

BOEM, an arm of the Interior Department, offered 81.2 million acres in the Gulf at a royalty rate of 12.5%, the lowest permitted by Trump's new tax law. Previously, as mandated by Biden's 2022 Inflation Reduction Act, oil companies were required to pay a minimum of 16.66% in royalties to the U.S. Treasury, states and other federal funds.

MORE:

Places the U.S. Government Warns Not to Travel Right Now

Trump's law lowered the rate to encourage industry participation in lease sales. U.S. crude oil prices are down about 20% this year, which can limit investment by drillers, though technological innovations in deep-sea drilling are ​expected to help boost Gulf production.

Offshore production accounts for about 15% of U.S. output, but has lagged onshore shale fields in recent years because of longer timelines and higher upfront costs.

The last Gulf sale in 2023 attracted 352 bids by 26 companies covering 1.73 ​million acres. It raised $382 million, the highest of any federal offshore lease sale since 2015.

(Reporting by Nichola GroomEditing by Bill Berkrot)

title: Spreading the Seeds of Change Along the San Antonio River
description:
The San Antonio River Foundation (River Foundation) is proud to continue spreading the seeds of change—from hands-on seed sorting to ecological talks that inspire deeper connections with the land.
Together with our partners, volunteers, and the San Antonio River Authority, we’re fostering a community that understands, protects, and celebrates the ecology of the San Antonio River.
This piece is contributed by the San Antonio River Foundation (River Foundation), who supports scientific and educational activities that promote and encourage the conservation, stewardship, restoration, preservation and enjoyment of the land and water resources of the San Antonio River Basin.
Disclaimer: The River Foundation is a separate entity from the San Antonio River Authority.
[image] The San Antonio River Foundation invites you to get involved!
text:
The San Antonio River Foundation (River Foundation) is proud to continue spreading the seeds of change—from hands-on seed sorting to ecological talks that inspire deeper connections with the land. Together with our partners, volunteers, and the San Antonio River Authority, we’re fostering a community that understands, protects, and celebrates the ecology of the San Antonio River.

This work is part of a larger story—one we celebrated at our recent Legacy Luncheon, themed “Where Community Meets the Current.” As we reflected with donors, supporters, and friends, the impact we make along the river is only possible because our community shows up again and again to move this work forward.

Every dollar raised through events like the Legacy Luncheon helps support programs that bring our four pillars — Arts & Culture, Ecology, Education, and Recreation — to life. From seed libraries to artist-led activations, from hands-on learning to outdoor public spaces that welcome everyone, these pillars guide our mission to create a river that belongs to all.

Seed Series: Get Hands-On With Native Seeds

Every second Wednesday this fall, we hosted our ongoing Seed Series. This family-friendly gathering invited the community to label, sort, and package native seeds for the Confluence Park Seed Library. Guided by our dedicated River Warrior Docent, Brooke Adams, participants learned about native plants, biodiversity, and the crucial role seeds play in sustaining the ecosystems along our river. The Native Plant Society of Texas—San Antonio Chapter and the Alamo Area Master Naturalists support this work.

Stay tuned for more ways to get involved when we re-sprout our Spring Seed Series in 2026!

Kill Your Lawn – On Tour makes a visit to Confluence Park

Last month, we hosted a packed event with the Kill Your Lawn – On Tour, featuring Joey Santore, the creator behind Crime Pays But Botany Doesn’t. The inspiring presentation encouraged the community to rethink traditional lawns and explore native plants as living infrastructure—plants that evolved exactly for this place, supporting the wildlife and soils that have been here long before us.

Participants learned about:

The ecological cost of turfgrass

How native plants conserve water and build healthier soils

The wild, beautiful life that emerges when we let nature lead

It was an incredible turnout and full of inspired conversations. Stay tuned—more opportunities to learn, rethink landscapes, and engage with local ecology are on the way.

Growing a More Resilient River Community

Whether you’re sorting seeds, attending a talk, exploring Confluence Park, or visiting the Seed Library, every moment of engagement helps deepen our collective commitment to the health of the San Antonio River. Together, we’re nurturing a future where native plants thrive, wildlife flourishes, and communities feel connected to the natural world around them. Let’s keep growing—one seed, one event, one conversation at a time.

This piece is contributed by the San Antonio River Foundation (River Foundation), who supports scientific and educational activities that promote and encourage the conservation, stewardship, restoration, preservation and enjoyment of the land and water resources of the San Antonio River Basin.

Disclaimer: The River Foundation is a separate entity from the San Antonio River Authority. Any donations would be solely to the River Foundation, which is a non-profit tax-exempt organization under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code.

[image]

The San Antonio River Foundation invites you to get involved! Join our next clean-up, sign up for a Confluence Park tour, volunteer with us, or explore the Mission Art Portals on our new ebike tours or come to our public events happening year-round. And don’t forget—the best way to stay up to date is by joining our newsletter and following us on Instagram and Facebook at @sariverfoundation.

If you’re inspired by this work and want to support it—through your time, your voice, or any contribution that feels meaningful—we’d love to have you as part of our river community. Whatever way you show up, it truly makes a difference.

We’re always growing something new, and we’d love to see you there.

text:
The House Natural Resources Committee advanced the ePermit Act (H.R.4503), introduced by Reps. Dusty Johnson (R-S.D.) and Scott Peters (D-Calif.). The bill aims to modernize and streamline the permitting process by transitioning to a fully-electronic permitting system.

Reps. April McClain Delaney (D-Md.) and Gabe Evans (R-Colo.) introduced the Rural Recovery Act (H.R.6462) to support rural communities impacted by disasters. The bill would direct the U.S. Department of Agriculture to establish a program focused on providing timely and effective support to rural communities affected by natural disasters. To learn more about disaster recovery, check out EESI’s Rapid Readout on the future of the Federal Emergency Management Administration.

Reps. Kristen McDonald Rivet (D-Mich.), Brian Fitzpatrick (R-Pa.), Emilia Sykes (D-Ohio), Rob Bresnahan (R-Pa.), and Tony Wied (R-Wis.) introduced the Affordable Clean Water Infrastructure Act (H.R.6464). This bill aims to support clean water infrastructure projects in rural, low-income, and high-need communities by strengthening the Clean Water State Revolving Fund, a federal-state financing program for water infrastructure projects.

Sen. Alex Padilla (D-Calif.), joined by Sens. Cynthia Lummis (R-Wyo.), Tim Sheehy (R-Wyo.), and Ron Wyden (D-Ore.), introduced S.3372, a bill to make existing tax exemptions permanent for wildfire survivors. Current tax exemptions passed by Congress are set to expire at the end of 2025. This bill would extend existing protections to allow homeowners tax payments on wildfire payouts.

name: Congress
title: Looming climate doomsday demands creativity, ambition, and societal transformation
description:
Despite the deluge of information about impending climate catastrophe, climate scientists and environmental activists have failed to move enough people to action.
Of course, as a child, I didn’t think anything about climate change.
But it was still some time before I began to appreciate the human impacts of climate change, and how people contribute to the problem.
That summer, Jamie and I convened students in the Princeton program to discuss the threat of climate change and plan a youth climate march to demand policy action.
We need a cacophony of voices calling for an end to fossil fuels and for the emergence of thriving communities.
text:
Eighty years after the founding of the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, and 55 years after the first Earth Day, humanity faces a growing profusion of existential threats. Most people—including politicians, business executives, and the financial institutions responsible for continued reliance on fossil fuels—know that climate change is a problem, and that it’s caused by human activities. But global leaders are floundering at the helm, and an informed populace hasn’t risen to the challenge.

Despite the deluge of information about impending climate catastrophe, climate scientists and environmental activists have failed to move enough people to action. As the co-founder of a youth organization advocating for climate justice—now working on fossil fuel policy at the Natural Resources Defense Council—I wish I knew why, given we have the solutions to transition our energy system. The youth climate strikes (as epitomized by activists such as Greta Thunberg) have lost steam, hard-won environmental policies are being overturned by every branch of our federal government, and 100-year climate disasters have become an annual occurrence. Apathy persists. If we knew why people turn a blind eye to the deterioration of the natural world around them, perhaps humanity wouldn’t be facing down doomsday. Nonetheless, it’s time to think more creatively about how to avert the worst of the climate crisis.

I’m 25 years old and a member of Gen-Z. Long before I was born, the scientific community (and the oil and gas industry) knew with confidence that the release of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere causes human-induced climate change (Artis 2024). This fact was communicated to global leaders and the public, most famously by James Hansen in testimony before Congress in 1986 (Hansen 1986). Yet, here we are, forced to endure the consequences of past indecision and inaction.

Growing up in Connecticut, I lived through back-to-back hurricanes Irene and Sandy in 2011 and 2012, respectively. Hurricane Sandy was one of the costliest storms in US history, and scientists have estimated that approximately $8.1 billion of Sandy’s damages were attributable to sea level rise caused by anthropogenic climate change (Strauss 2021). Of course, as a child, I didn’t think anything about climate change. I enjoyed the days off from school and the novelty of playing games by candle and lamp-light while rain crashed from the sky overhead. “Global warming” as I knew it was still a distant problem. On frequent visits to the Mystic Aquarium, home to several beluga whales, I learned about habitat loss and the threat a warming planet poses to Arctic species. At the beach near my childhood home, I learned about sea level rise and plastic pollution threatening our coastline along Long Island Sound. But it was still some time before I began to appreciate the human impacts of climate change, and how people contribute to the problem.

In the summer of 2017, I met Jamie Margolin at a summer program for high schoolers at Princeton University. Before arriving in New Jersey, wildfires in California and Canada had blanketed her hometown of Seattle, Washington, in a cloud of smoke and ash. She was the first person that I remember drawing a causal link between political support for oil and gas, and the impacts of so-called natural disasters that she was experiencing. After meeting Jamie, I recognized that climate change was not an unstoppable force of nature, but rather a political outcome that all of us can affect.

That summer, Jamie and I convened students in the Princeton program to discuss the threat of climate change and plan a youth climate march to demand policy action. This eventually led us to found Zero Hour, a global youth-led climate justice organization advocating to end the era of fossil fuels. Much like the idea behind the Doomsday Clock, we chose the name Zero Hour to convey a sense of urgency: that we were out of time to delay action on climate change any further. In fact, it was through these early organizing efforts that I first learned about the Doomsday Clock and the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists; Arielle Martinez-Cohen, another organizer, let us use her song, “Two Minutes to Midnight,” for the video of Zero Hour’s Youth Climate March in Washington, DC (Martinez-Cohen 2018).

Since then, the Doomsday Clock has continued to tick, tick away, and it is now at 89 seconds to midnight.

These youth climate marches, led by Zero Hour organizers on every continent, helped to ignite a youth-led movement for climate justice. We were mobilizing our peers for the first time—a generation that was coming to terms with the fact that they’d experienced climate change their whole lives without anything being done about it from the people in power. In 2019, we helped to lead some of the biggest climate strikes in the United States, and welcomed Greta Thunberg to the United States to join us. We didn’t wait for approval, and didn’t care that so many people, even in the environmental movement, thought that we didn’t have the experience or education to lead a movement. We did it anyway, and we forged an intergenerational movement in the process.

It is time for the environmental movement to take risks and shake things up again. It’s time to build up the youngest generations of people to organize for climate justice again, and the Bulletin can help do that. Zero Hour made its mark on the world when Instagram was still being used to share selfies and candid shots—entirely unlike the manicured, influencer-heavy, ad-driven behemoth that the platform has become. Social media was our digital playground, and it’s a major reason why Zero Hour and other youth climate organizations have mobilized as many people as we have. Over the past several years, the media environment has continued to change—short-form videos now dominate social media and 54 percent of people get at least some of their news from these platforms (Pew Research 2025). Like the risks conveyed by the Doomsday Clock, attention is now counted in seconds, not minutes.

Social media has democratized the spread of information—today, any strong communicator can gain an avid audience—but it has also increased the challenge of communicating about complex, evidence-based topics like climate change. Like so many other young people, I often scroll on social media for entertainment and distraction, not to seek out news or ways to take action. In an era where there are limitless flows of content competing for the public’s attention, the climate movement needs to spark excitement instead of dread to capture the attention of people inundated with information. Where facts and science have failed, storytelling that evokes an emotional response may still succeed. The Bulletin can, and should, embrace this new horizon of social media to inform and activate Gen-Z and Gen-Alpha again.

In today’s political climate, strongly-held, ill-informed opinions trump facts, science, and expertise—any headline featuring RFK Jr. could tell you that. But when it comes to climate change, the science is settled: Greenhouse gas emissions, which have dramatically increased because of human activities, are causing the Earth to warm, and making the planet a far more dangerous and unpredictable place for human life.

When I joined the fight to end the era of fossil fuels, I presumed that when people know better, they do better. That belief—that climate education for the masses will lead to transformational shifts in our energy system and ways of living—is still widely held across the environmental movement. Yet, climate projections, models, and warnings from the world’s leading scientists urging policymakers to adopt policies to limit warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius have been unsuccessful at convincing policy makers or the public to aggressively fight to end the era of fossil fuels. Enough about carbon reduction, it’s time to rally people around a transformation of our societies beyond just addressing emissions.

The Green New Deal is one ambitious proposal that does that. This is the kind of societal transformation that people deserve, and it leaves room to imagine what achieving it looks like wherever you live. A Green New Deal means environmental justice for everyone living in the colossal shadow of the oil and gas industry, but it also calls for universal healthcare, universal access to well-resourced and high-quality education, and a guarantee of good-paying union jobs. Adoption of a Green New Deal means winning the fight against climate change by doing more than meeting the bare minimum needs of the population. It is a vision for the future that humanity can thrive in, rather than getting by on scraps from the oligarchy. A Green New Deal is rooted in justice, and whether you live in remote Alaska, rural Alabama, or coastal Connecticut, the Green New Deal can be what it needs to be for your community.

When the Green New Deal rose to national prominence, right-wing politicians backed by corporate political action committees spent billions branding it as a radical socialist scam (Downie 2023). Vocal proponents in Congress, and even civil society advocates, have recently shied away from demanding a Green New Deal because it’s been bludgeoned in the court of public opinion by conservative media, trade groups like the American Petroleum Institute, and politicians like Donald Trump, who demonizes it as the “Green New Scam” (Thompson 2025). But while the Green New Deal has evoked the ire of corporations and the political elite, people across the political spectrum like the policy proposals at their core (Adcox 2024).

When the business-as-usual—or business-but-worse—policies of the current administration fail to deliver an affordable and safe future for all Americans, then climate and environmental activists, scientists, and well-informed politicians should have an ambitious and appealing alternative to offer them. The Green New Deal remains that alternative, even if it needs new framing for mass appeal. For too long, the climate movement has been plagued by a lack of imagination for a world beyond fossil fuels, and the mainstream environmental movement has failed to communicate the importance of dismantling the systems of oppression that have enabled the exploitation of people and nature for profit for hundreds of years. As a movement, we are reacting to every attack on the environment and public health coming out of the government, but this reactivity is why we’re struggling to build a movement with a long-term vision post-exploitation of nature and people.

We need more scientists, more business leaders, more journalists—more people everywhere—to step up and call for systemic changes to the way our society exists. We need a cacophony of voices calling for an end to fossil fuels and for the emergence of thriving communities. On its eightieth anniversary, I hope these words inspire the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists to be a part of that cacophony of voices calling for radical transformation of our communities from leaders in power, and urge the public to demand their leaders achieve that transformation.

text:
Environmental groups, clean energy advocates applaud approval of project that could power 200,000 homes

[RUSH TWP, CENTRE COUNTY] – In a 2-1 vote on Tuesday evening, the Rush Township Supervisors in Centre County, Pennsylvania approved the pending permit for the renewable energy project known as Black Moshannon Solar.

The proposed solar project would generate 265 megawatts of electricity, enough to power 200,000 homes annually. At the same time, the project is being heralded for utilizing nearly 2,000 acres of toxic mineland, reclaiming otherwise unusable land, and including mineland clean-up as part of the project’s development. The project’s developers have committed to introducing pollinators and pollinator-friendly ground cover beneath the solar arrays, conducting water quality and soil studies throughout development and operations, and taking steps to enhance the soil by using lime to neutralize mining contamination and encourage vegetation to grow on the site.

The Black Moshannon Solar project is also expected to provide more than $5 million in tax revenue to support the Phillipsburg-Osceola Area School District and more than $700,000 in direct tax payments to Centre County.

In response to the approval of the permit proposal by Rush Township, statewide environmental group leaders and nonprofit clean energy advocates release the following statements:

“The bipartisan group of Rush Township Supervisors who got this proposal over the finish line should pat themselves on the back for this groundbreaking project,” stated David Masur, Executive Director for the statewide nonprofit organization PennEnvironment. “We are hopeful that other local government officials across Pennsylvania will follow Rush Township’s lead and implement similar, much-needed solar projects all across the Keystone State.”

“The Rush Township Supervisors are establishing productive farmland and sustainable energy infrastructure for future generations,” noted Jim Gregory, Executive Director, Conservative Energy Network-Pennsylvania. “In forty years, their forward-thinking decisions will be recognized as catalysts for environmental protection, public health improvements, and economic prosperity. The Conservative Energy Network-Pennsylvania commends their responsible leadership and dedication to the community’s long-term well-being.”

“The Black Moshannon Solar project is a perfect example of how renewable energy, natural resource conservation, and community benefits can align. This truly is a win-win-win for the community,” stated Nate Reagle, the Sierra Club Pennsylvania Chapter’s Clean Energy Program Advocate.

“As veterans, we understand what it means to serve something greater than ourselves,” said Moises Montalvo, Pennsylvania Lead Organizer for Veterans Power America. “Projects like Black Moshannon Solar give us a chance to continue that service—by strengthening our nation’s energy security, creating jobs for working families, and leaving behind a cleaner, safer country for future generations.”

“Approval of the Black Moshannon Solar project is a victory for the people of Rush Township, a victory for clean energy, and a victory for a sustainable economy,” stated Tom Pike, Clean Air Council Director of Campaigns. “This is the kind of forward-thinking work that communities across the Commonwealth should be looking to replicate.”

“This project is a powerful example of how local communities and elected officials are coming together to embrace solar energy. By redeveloping polluted lands for clean energy production, we can transform environmental liabilities into long-term economic and environmental assets, all while helping to lower rising energy costs for Pennsylvanians. It’s a no-brainer, and we hope other communities across the commonwealth will join in realizing the firsthand benefits of going solar,” said Abby Jones, Vice President of Legal & Policy at PennFuture.

###

The PennEnvironment Research & Policy Center is dedicated to protecting our air, water and open spaces. We work to protect the places we love, advance the environmental values we share, and win real results for our environment. For more information, visit www.pennenvironmentcenter.org.

The Conservative Energy Network-Pennsylvania works to champion secure, reliable and affordable clean Keystone energy for Commonwealth ratepayers. For more information, please visit https://conservativeenergynetwork.org/cen-pa/.

Veterans Power America is a national network of veterans organizing to advance clean energy, create good-paying jobs, and strengthen America’s energy independence. As part of the veterans organization Common Defense, VPA empowers those who served to continue their mission at home—fighting for a secure, sustainable future powered by American clean energy. For more information visit www.veteranspoweramerica.org.

The Sierra Club, established in 1892, is the oldest and largest grassroots non-profit environmental organization in the country. The Pennsylvania Chapter has nearly 30,000 members across the state.

Clean Air Council is a member-supported environmental organization serving Pennsylvania and the surrounding regions. The Council is dedicated to protecting everyone’s right to a healthy environment. The Council works through a broad array of sustainability and public health initiatives, including public education, community action, government oversight, and enforcement of environmental laws. For more information, please visitwww.cleanair.org.

title: Why this B.C. pulp mill wants to produce hydrogen | CBC News
description:
A $21-million green hydrogen production facility is set to be built inside the Kruger Pulp Mill in Kamloops, B.C.
The construction of the 10-megawatt facility, called the Kamloops Clean Energy Centre, is a collaborative effort between the Tk̓emlúps te Secwépemc Nation, Elemental Clean Fuels and Kruger Kamloops Pulp.
The project prompted questions over why a pulp mill is choosing to produce hydrogen, and how it will be done.
The Kruger Pulp Mill makes paper and pulp products using wood.
“The Kamloops Clean Energy Centre reflects our commitment to sustainability, economic self-determination, and highlights our leadership in advancing innovative, local clean energy solutions," said Kúkwpi7 (Chief) Rosanne Casimir of Tk̓emlúps te Secwépemc.
text:
A $21-million green hydrogen production facility is set to be built inside the Kruger Pulp Mill in Kamloops, B.C.

The goal of the project is decarbonizing and reducing the mill's reliance on natural gas, said Irene Preto, the general manager of Kruger Kamloops Pulp.

The construction of the 10-megawatt facility, called the Kamloops Clean Energy Centre, is a collaborative effort between the Tk̓emlúps te Secwépemc Nation, Elemental Clean Fuels and Kruger Kamloops Pulp.

On Dec. 8, Sc.wén̓wen , the economic division of the nation, announced the novel project.

The project prompted questions over why a pulp mill is choosing to produce hydrogen, and how it will be done. Here's what you need to know.

Why does a pulp mill want to produce hydrogen?

The Kruger Pulp Mill makes paper and pulp products using wood.

A part of its manufacturing process, the lime kiln, is particularly energy-intensive and requires a lot of heat — which is currently derived from burning natural gas.

"To be able to decarbonize the natural gas out of our lime kiln is a really big step forward towards our goal of becoming more renewable," said Preto.

The mill plans to replace 16 per cent of the natural gas used in the lime kiln with hydrogen.

When hydrogen is burned, rather than creating carbon dioxide, it creates water and heat.

Why hydrogen?

When hydrogen atoms are isolated, they can store and transport a lot of energy, similar to other energy-rich products like natural gas.

Hydrogen atoms are reactive, meaning they usually like to be combined with other atoms to form molecules — unless a lot of energy is present.

How is hydrogen energy produced?

Production is done in two ways: either by separating hydrogen from a carbon-rich molecule like methane (CH4), or from water (H2O).

But when carbon-containing molecules like coal or methane are burned for hydrogen production, carbon dioxide is released as a byproduct, leading to greenhouse gas emissions.

Some facilities capture and store the released carbon dioxide to minimize greenhouse gas emissions.

Alternatively, a process called electrolysis — which will be used by Kruger — uses electricity to split water molecules into oxygen and hydrogen atoms.

Preto says the resulting oxygen atoms will be used to strengthen the pulp the mill produces.

When the electricity for electrolysis comes from a renewable source, like wind or hydroelectric dams, the product is called green hydrogen.

Where is the electricity for electrolysis coming from?

The electricity comes from the B.C. Hydro grid — but it is actually produced at the pulp mill from wood byproducts.

Wood byproducts are burned to create steam, which then turns a turbine and generates electricity.

The process is called biomass cogeneration, and the mill subsequently sells the resulting electricity to B.C. Hydro, part of which will be used for electrolysis.

Why replace natural gas?

Zachary Steele, the CEO of Elemental Green Fuels — the developer of the project — said in this case, replacing natural gas combustion with green hydrogen will reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

“We're going to reduce the emissions by 7,000 tonnes of CO2 per year. That's the equivalent of taking 1,200 to 1,500 vehicles off the road,” he said.

Steele said simply using electricity from B.C. Hydro to power the kiln is not feasible, because it would require so much power it would stress the grid.

When will it be built?

Kruger received funding for the project from Natural Resources Canada through an Indigenous clean energy fund.

“The Kamloops Clean Energy Centre reflects our commitment to sustainability, economic self-determination, and highlights our leadership in advancing innovative, local clean energy solutions," said Kúkwpi7 (Chief) Rosanne Casimir of Tk̓emlúps te Secwépemc.

The project is still being designed, and is a ways off from being operational.

Steele said the final investment decision is expected sometime in 2026, with construction beginning after that.
